poem:
**Generator**

In Bucha, three engineers lean over a generator  
like priests over a small, stubborn altar,  
a heat gun blowing salvation into a frozen filter.  
The mayor apologizes for coffee—  
even his office machine has surrendered.  

Outside, the traffic lights forget their colors,  
shops go dim,  
and winter tries again  
to make a city uninhabitable.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘An attempt to break people’: Bucha holds out amid Russia’s weaponisation of winter Outside the main pumping station for Bucha, three engineers, bundled up in parkas, are working on the emergency generator keeping the Ukrainian city supplied with water. One holds a heat gun to the generator’s filter in an effort to unfreeze it, his face reddened by blowing snow and a daytime temperature of -12C (10.4F). Watching attentively is the city’s mayor, Anatolii Fedoruk. The generator in his office is also frozen when the Guardian visits and he apologises for the lack of coffee. Four years ago, in the first days of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Bucha and the neighbouring city of Irpinbecame emblematic of the brutality of Moscow’s brief occupation of this area amid the murder of civilians. Interactive Bucha and Irpin were briefly occupied by Russia at the start of the invasion. While the buildings in Bucha have largely been repaired, and the Russians pushed away long ago, Ukraine’s long war is still very much being felt here – most profoundly after Russia attacked energy infrastructure as temperatures dropped to almost -20C and a national state of emergency was declared. And while energy rationing was already in force in Bucha this winter, the latest attacks have exacerbated an already difficult situation. Arriving in the city on a day of harsh cold and falling snow, traffic lights are dark and residential blocks and many shops unlit due to the latest rolling power outage. In the Battkava cafe, Oleksandr". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
